the double folded towel and clamps is a better idea idea than drying it in the bucket if pressed for time because it increases surface area for the water to evaporate off, reducing time. I just would use another 5-gallon bucket that has holes in the side to pour it into, and let it dry that way, without bothering to take it out and wrap it all up. After siphoning off the water you could leave a little in to put it all in suspension again, then when it's poured into the towel, the sand will sink to the bottom and can be skimmed off at the end. Or will probably be mostly stuck at the bottom of the bucket, if you pour carefully without agitating first.

Clay making is incredibly fascinating, especially when you get the end results of that fine.

You put the dirt in a bucket or container,
You mix it with water, let all of the dirt soak to the bottom, pour out the water leaving the rocks and debris at the bottom.
After letting it sit , pouring the water at the top out.
Dumping the bucket through the strainer to get a lot of the sand and debris out.
Altering it from container to take container to get all of the sand out.
Wrapping it into a cloth, hang it up to drip dry.
Let the rest of the water absorb into a cloth or paper towel.
And that is all it takes to make clay!

I just pour the wet clay into big pans and let it dry in the sun. Mix once and a while with the scraper till its thick to use. Or dry it and  run it through a rock tumbler to a powder. Kitty litter can be tumbled into a powder as well. Thats clay.

i have done something somewhat similar to this with actual clay dug from a waterfall.  made a super thin slurry with it then ran it through a spagetti strainer then through one of those reusable coffee filters to remover the solid particulates and then let it sit in a vat made of plaster of paris to remove the water leaving the solid clay behind.

One recommendation I'd make regarding the video straining clay slurry is to NOT pour in the center for the whole batch since mere pressure of new slurry will force impurities through your strainer. Instead, move the stream slowly around and around the usable wire surface so the whole mesh is used, not just the inch in the center and splash up the sides. I see this is done later in the video but it might not be readily noticeable.

People might already know this, but impurities in a fired clay expand and contract at different rates, leading to cracking ,or worse, explosions. Careful attention at the straining/purification stage is well worth the time and effort to insure a better result in fire. Usefulness extends from containers, cooling, carry (and art) but also light duty tools and utensils like bowls and spoons.

The process of getting clay is getting the water out as much as you can but have enough to have useful clay. If you don't want to use a towel or clothes that results in a horrifying mess. Water evaporates so you can either leave it outside in the sun... don't use plastic it will melt if too hot. Or use a pot or oven pan like a bread one and turn the oven on, not too high clay can still burn. I believe you would want to keep it around 212f.

Lifehack to get this clay if you're not sure about digging deep into the ground:
If you live near a waterway where clay is commonly found, try putting on your rainboots and walking along the side as close as is comfortable for you. (This works especially best after it has rained and the clay-dirt turns muddy) You will most likely have that sticky clay-dirt mud caked on your boots. You can then grab some gloves and scrape off the clay-mud into a container before using the filtering process down in this video.
Hope this helps someone out there 😊

You guys should try (Western) raku-style firing.  It's pretty unique and low temp, so much easier DIY than traditional western firing.  You basically bury the pots into a trashcan or barrel full of sawdust (or woodshavings or shredded paper).  The sawdust burns unevenly across the surface of the clay and makes interesting colors and patterns, even when you don't use glaze.  Some people don't even bisque fire the clay first -- just let the burning sawdust do the work.  Which makes for a very beginner-friendly, inexpensive process.  If you do do it, though, be careful about storing the sawdust and wood shavings; they can actually spontaneously combust.

theres a much, much eaisier way to do this! just find a spot with some hard soil on the top, dig down a few centimetres, pour on some water, then pick at it with a stick untill you have some loose mud, then knead it, a bit like bread untill you have a nice texture. it lasts, although it might have a few sticks. and it takes about 20- 30 minutes. not the best for quality sculptures though

Unless you're trying to light speed this process, try placing an appropriate length of cotton rope in the slurry with one end in an empty container. Through osmosis, the water will wick up the rope and dump the water into the empty container leaving the solids behind. As the slurry settles more and the water column "rises", the wick will draw off more liquids and leave the clay behind. Just sayin'.

how to make clay
step 1 ) pick up dirt that has a small, fine granular size that classifies it as mostly clay
congratulations. you can spot it easily by cutting it down the middle, if it is mostly smooth (known as "glass" or "glassing" unofficially) you have mostly clay in your hands. it holds moisture really well though so don't expect to be able to sift it. it'll most likely clump together way too much.

To see what is actually happening, you need to take some of the river dirt and put it in a glass jar. If you shake it like crazy, like a paint mixer, and then let it settle you will get a picture of the components of soil.After you let it settle, it will separate itself into a series of layers. The bottom layer will be gravel and rocks, then there will be sand. Then comes the clay - that is what you are after. On top of that is the loam and on top of that is the organics. I hope you get an idea of what you are trying to tell us from this process.....

Take your liquid clay (slip) and poor it on to a cookie sheet. Let it dry out completely. Scrape the dried clay off of the sheet, and crush the pieces into a fine powder. Add small amounts of water, a few drops at a time, and stir until the clay is the consistency you want it at. Don't do the towel thing shown here. It's messy, ruins the towel, and makes it harder to recover. The cookie sheet can be washed normally afterwards as well, with no ill effects.

dude when clay is really watery at any degree, its called slip. and putting it on a slab of plaster (casting plaster works best not plaster for walls) is the best method to absorb the water, even when its really runny, make a plaster bowl mold and poor it in. its quick and easy and you dont have to do all that straining in the towel. get a flat plaster slab and work the clay to remove air bubbles, like kneeding dough, but its called wedging also a smooth surface is a terrible place to work with clay on, clay sticks to it really easily especially when its in a lump but still pretty wet, the best surface to use is a wooden surface, un varnished, and not your mums antique table. trust me im a qualified ceramicist

I have been digging up clay from my local beach. The sea defenses are poor and it has been eroding a field, washing mud and clay onto the beach. The mud gets washed away but the clay has sinks and is more resilient. It clumps together on and in the sand and pretty easy to collect and pure.

but you also want some amout of dense particles like sand in a clay, otherwise it would be fragile (like porcelain).. and also your pottery can break in a firing process when the clay is too clean, so if you would do everything by yourself I would suggest you have some dense particles in the clay.. or even organic matter (it will burn down and leave the clay more porous)

9/10 cases if you try to make this clay into a pot and fire it - it will crack. You filtered a lot of sand away (you made the clay too "sleek") and you need silica in it to melt during the firing - a pot made with clay is basically just one notch away from being a glass bowl.
You can remedy that by simply adding a bit of fine sand to it, or powdered silica.
In the past when potters had only the locally available clay to work with they would put field boulders in furnaces, make them red hot, then douse them with water to make them crack and then pulverise them further (apparently it gives you finer grains than just adding sand).

Step 1: take dirt from backyard

Step 2: wash the dirt

Step 3: keep pouring in different cups to remove sand

Step 4: put in a bag to dry the clay

Step 5: if wasn't dried enough (and looks like diarreah) put toilet paper and wrap it around the clay or leave it out for longer

Step 6: mold it and wait for the clay 2 dry

Hmmm.  Making stuff that looks and feels like clay is pretty easy, but I'm not sure that fine river mud will actually fire like a true clay (unless you're lucky and happen to find a river with a clay deposit).  Firing actual clay results in vitrification, and that's what you need for pottery.  Maybe you out to try to test fire some of this stuff to make sure it works...otherwise you just made stinky grey play-doh.

That clay is going to be too "SHORT." You need to add some fine and medium course refractory materials in to the clay to prevent cracking and breaking. AKA, GROG. Temper your clay.

Take some fire brick and red brick, and smash it to fine pieces. Then experiment and add different percents to small batches. Let them dry to see how much then CRACK. you want to get a batch that has little to no cracking. (You may never get rid of all the cracking.)

The clay may be too short to work with, even after you try and add some Grog to it

You can also fire small pieces of the clay, crush kit then add it back to the raw clay.

Adding 5-7% bentonite clay can help with plasticity, too much will cause excessive shrinking.

Then once you have a tested working recipe, you need to "ferment" the clay. The clay has a portion of unsaturated clay particulate that needs to be fully hydrated. Also some other processes in this that will "lengthen" the clay.

Leave the finished clay mixture in a plastic bag for 2 weeks. Once it has that "earthy" smell to it, it should be ready for working.

It's most likely going to be a low fire clay. You can get pyro cones to see what cone your clay fires at.

Keep salt away from this. Clay particles are small enough that the electrostatic charge at the faces of the crystals actually can make the clay particles stick together (that's what makes it stick when it's dry), and adding salt makes that process MUCH faster.

Second, the process of allowing dirt to settle in a column of water is simple, but powerful. Different clays have different sized particles and fall at different rates through the water column. If you time it right, you can actually filter out specific clays. It takes a lot of preparation, a careful hand, and dedication (it takes 48 hours to do, and requires to you to be there whenever the clay is ready, regardless of things like sleep schedules and meal times), but it can be done .

I live in the East of England, which was formed of the debris left by retreating glaciers, which means we have no hard rocks, hence a flat landscape, based on clay layers, mainly 'London' and 'Boulder'. Two streets from my home was, at one time, a huge brickworks, and the clay pits are still there. The clay, known as 'Pug' is near the surface and easy to obtain. If I needed clay in a survival situation, I'd dig for it on the inside of a river bend, where deposition takes place, preferably on the end of the bend that faces downriver.

Potters dry clay slurry by pouring or scooping the soupy clay onto big, thick sheets of highly dried plaster of Paris. The plaster wicks away the moisture evenly and slowly so hard dry lumps don't form. Potters call the the plaster of Paris sheets, "bats."Home potters usually make the bats themselves by pouring mixed plaster of Paris into wooden, take-apart forms lined with plastic sheeting (cling wrap will do). Dimensions, about 1-1/2 to 2 feet by 2 to 3 feet by about 2 or 3 inches thick. You can leave on the plastic, I suppose, but I always took it off. I also took off the forms (1"x2" pieces of wood).The bats MUST be dried very well and must be dried after each use. I've heard of people using cat litter trays as a form, but I've never done that. I imagine the plaster would be difficult to remove. Caution, newly dried plaster is easy to break. I've also seen people put a top mold of another tray on the wet plaster. That forms a lip around the top, but I've never seen the need for that. I like the bats to be flat on the top and bottom.

Here in India, there is an easier way to make clay.
Just get/buy a specific type of rock found in the river bed.
Smash it.
Add it to water.
Drain the water after a while.
Take the moisture clay.
Put it on a cover.
Stamp it.
Get it together.
Repeat the last two steps a few times.
The clay will be ready when you get the right consistency.

Fun stuff. I am getting clay as a byproduct of making green sand for casting from my local dirt. . My processing containers hold about 20 gallons with a bulkhead on the side near the bottom. Standpipes of various lengths can be used to drain liquid from the top. A plastic colander is used to remove large bits. A wire strainer is used between the first and 2nd containers.

One can control where the fine mesh sand goes by varying the setting time of the first container. Short times put it in the clay, longer time leave it with the sand.

Pinch pots are fun and easy to make.  There's also a technique called "wedging" to help work out more bubbles.  Wedging is running the clay through a wire.  Potters also call thick clay water "slip" and use it like glue for a lot of hand-built creations.  Also, casting some plaster slabs to set the overly wet clay on will help with the drying process.
